enraged.definition: To fill with rage; to provoke to frenzy or madness; to make furious.
Angered, made furious, made full of rage.

fuming.definition: To expose (something) to fumes; specifically, to expose wood, etc., to ammonia in order to produce dark tints.
The act of one who fumes or shows suppressed anger.

repulsed.example: to repulse an assault; to repulse the enemy

disgusted.definition: To cause an intense dislike for something.
disgusted.example: It disgusts me to see her chew with her mouth open.
The sight of the squirming mass of maggots left me disgusted.

apprehensive.definition: Anticipating something with anxiety or fear.

pessimistic.definition: Marked by pessimism and little hopefulness; expecting the worst.
pessimistic.example: a pessimistic view of the future

alienated.definition: To convey or transfer to another, as title, property, or right; to part voluntarily with ownership of.

panicked.definition: Experiencing or in a state of panic.

despair.definition: Loss of hope; utter hopelessness; complete despondency.
despair.example: He turned around in despair, aware that he was not going to survive

despair.definition: To give up as beyond hope or expectation; to despair of.

frightened.definition: To cause to feel fear; to scare; to cause to feel alarm or fright.
frightened.example: Avery puts a sheet over her head, pretending to be a ghost to frighten Emily.

furious.example: a furious animal; parent furious at their child's behaviour

frustrated.definition: To disappoint or defeat; to vex by depriving of something expected or desired.
frustrated.example: It frustrates me to do all this work and then lose it all.

troubled.definition: To disturb, stir up, agitate (a medium, especially water).

morose.definition: Sullen, gloomy; showing a brooding ill humour.

miserable.definition: In a state of misery: very sad, ill, or poor.

despondent.definition: In low spirits from loss of hope or courage.

depressed.example: Depress the upper lever to start the machine.

hopeless.definition: Without hope; despairing; not expecting anything positive.

stressed.definition: To apply force to (a body or structure) causing strain.

angry.example: An angry mob started looting the warehouse.

worried.definition: Thinking about unpleasant things that have happened or that might happen; feeling afraid and unhappy.
worried.example: She was worried about her son who had been sent off to fight in the war.

worried.definition: To be troubled; to give way to mental anxiety or doubt.
worried.example: Stop worrying about your test, it’ll be fine.

concerned.definition: To relate or belong to; to have reference to or connection with; to affect the interest of; to be of importance to.

concerned.example: There was a concerned expression on her face as I told her the news.

disappointed.definition: To sadden or displease (someone) by underperforming, or by not delivering something promised or hoped for.
disappointed.example: His lack of respect disappointed her.

disappointed.definition: Defeated of expectations or hope; experiencing disappointment; let down.
disappointed.example: After all his anticipation, the trip left him deeply disappointed.

discouraged.definition: To extinguish the courage of; to dishearten; to depress the spirits of; to deprive of confidence; to deject.
discouraged.example: Don't be discouraged by the amount of work left to do: you'll finish it in good time.

discouraged.definition: Having lost confidence or hope; dejected; disheartened.

lonely.definition: Unhappy because of feeling isolated from contact with other people.

sullen.definition: One who is solitary, or lives alone; a hermit.
Having a brooding ill temper; sulky.

desolate.example: a desolate isle; a desolate wilderness; a desolate house

tense.definition: (grammar) Any of the forms of a verb which distinguish when an action or state of being occurs or exists.

irritated.definition: To provoke impatience, anger, or displeasure in.

down.example: I love almost everything about my job. The only down is that I can't take Saturdays off.

down.definition: To knock (someone or something) down; to cause to come down, to fell.
down.example: A single rifle shot downed the mighty beast.
Mary seems very down since she split up with her boyfriend.

down.definition: From a higher position to a lower one; downwards.
down.example: The cat jumped down from the table.

down.definition: From the higher end to the lower of.
down.example: The ball rolled down the hill.

sad.definition: To make melancholy; to sadden or grieve (someone).

disheartened.definition: To discourage someone by removing their enthusiasm or courage.

exhausted.definition: To draw or let out wholly; to drain off completely
exhausted.example: Moisture of the earth is exhausted by evaporation.

exhausted.definition: Very tired; in a state of exhaustion.
exhausted.example: The exhausted man fell asleep immediately.

spent.example: He spends far more on gambling than he does on living proper.

shocked.definition: To cause to be emotionally shocked, to cause (someone) to feel surprised and upset.
To collect, or make up, into a shock or shocks; to stook.
Surprised, startled, confused, or taken aback.

stunned.definition: To incapacitate; especially by inducing disorientation or unconsciousness.
stunned.example: Bill tried to stun the snake by striking it on the head.

stunned.definition: Unable to act or respond; dazed; shocked.

restless.example: The night before his wedding was a restless one.

annoyed.definition: To disturb or irritate, especially by continued or repeated acts; to bother with unpleasant deeds.
annoyed.example: Marc loved his sister, but when she annoyed him he wanted to switch her off.

annoyed.definition: Troubled, irritated by something unwanted or unliked (an annoyance); vexed.

peeved.example: He was peeved to note that his hard work had been undone.

apathetic.definition: Void of feeling; not susceptible of deep emotion

bored.definition: Suffering from boredom; mildly annoyed and restless through having nothing to do

tired.definition: To seize, pull, and tear prey, as a hawk does.
In need of some rest or sleep.

fatigued.definition: To tire or make weary by physical or mental exertion

drained.definition: Lacking motivation and energy; very tired; knackered.
drained.example: I felt so drained after that three-hour exam that I wanted to sleep for the next week.

surprised.definition: To cause (someone) to feel unusually alarmed or delighted by something unexpected.
surprised.example: It surprises me that I owe twice as much as I thought I did.

surprised.definition: Caused to feel surprise, amazement or wonder, or showing an emotion due to an unexpected event.

pleased.definition: To make happy or satisfy; to give pleasure to.

pleasant.definition: Giving a sense of happy satisfaction or enjoyment.

pleasant.example: It wasn't so hot outside, but pleasant enough to have lunch in the garden.

at ease.definition: (in a person) The state of being calm; peacefulness; absence of worry, anger, fear or other strong negative emotion.

calm.definition: (in a person) The state of being calm; peacefulness; absence of worry, anger, fear or other strong negative emotion.
(of a person) Peaceful, quiet, especially free from anger and anxiety.

relaxed.definition: Having an easy-going mood or temperament.
relaxed.example: He's a relaxed kind of guy, he never lets himself get upset.

mellow.definition: To make mellow; to relax or soften.
mellow.example: The fervour of early feeling is tempered and mellowed by the ripeness of age.

mellow.definition: Soft or tender by reason of ripeness; having a tender pulp.

sleepy.definition: The gum that builds up in the eye; sleep, gound.
Tired; feeling the need for sleep.

upbeat.definition: An unaccented beat at the start of a musical phrase.
upbeat.example: The conductor said: I give you three beats for nothing and then you come in on the upbeat.

upbeat.definition: Having a fast pace, tempo, or beat.
upbeat.example: The notes are easy, but it's an upbeat tune and should be played fairly quickly.

happy.definition: A happy event, thing, person, etc.
Preceded by the: happy people as a group.
Often followed by up: to become happy; to brighten up, to cheer up.
Having a feeling arising from a consciousness of well-being or of enjoyment; enjoying good of any kind, such as comfort, peace, or tranquillity; blissful, contented, joyous.

easygoing.definition: (of a person) calm, relaxed, casual and informal

secure.definition: To make safe; to relieve from apprehensions of, or exposure to, danger; to guard; to protect.
Free from attack or danger; protected.

chill.definition: A moderate, but uncomfortable and penetrating coldness.
chill.example: There was a chill in the air.

chill.definition: To lower the temperature of something; to cool

chill.example: A chill wind was blowing down the street.

festive.definition: Having the atmosphere, decoration, or attitude of a festival, holiday, or celebration.
festive.example: The room was decked out in festive streamers, with flowers everywhere.

motivated.definition: To provide someone with an incentive to do something; to encourage.
motivated.example: The weekly staff meeting was meant to motivate employees.

motivated.definition: Enthusiastic, especially about striving toward a goal.
motivated.example: We're looking for a highly motivated individual who will fit into our fast-paced corporate culture.

focused.definition: (followed by on or upon) To concentrate one's attention.
focused.example: I have to focus on my work.

focused.definition: Directing all one's efforts towards achieving a particular goal.

optimistic.definition: Expecting the best in all possible ways.

hopeful.definition: Someone who is hoping for success or victory, especially as a candidate in a political election.
hopeful.example: Several presidential hopefuls are campaigning in New Hampshire this week.
I am hopeful that I will recover from the disease.

content.definition: To give contentment or satisfaction; to satisfy; to make happy.
content.example: You can't have any more - you'll have to content yourself with what you already have.

satisfied.definition: To do enough for; to meet the needs of; to fulfill the wishes or requirements of.
satisfied.example: I'm not satisfied with the quality of the food here.

restful.example: After a hard day, Sue found the beauty of the park especially restful.

thoughtful.example: Most thoughtful people eventually solve the puzzle.

peaceful.definition: Not at war or disturbed by strife or turmoil.

exhilarated.definition: To cheer, to cheer up, to gladden, to make happy.
exhilarated.example: Good news exhilarates the mind; wine exhilarates the drinker.

complacent.definition: Uncritically satisfied with oneself or one's achievements; smug.

tranquil.definition: Free from emotional or mental disturbance.

inspired.definition: To infuse into the mind; to communicate to the spirit; to convey, as by a divine or supernatural influence; to disclose preternaturally; to produce in, as by inspiration.

inspired.example: The actor's inspired performance of Hamlet's soliloquy left the audience dumbfounded.

proud.definition: Feeling honoured (by something); feeling happy or satisfied about an event or fact; gratified.
proud.example: I am proud of Sivu’s schoolwork.

playful.definition: Liking play, prone to play frequently, such as a child or kitten; rather sportive.
playful.example: Actually, we are pretty playful in our romantic life.

loving.definition: (usually transitive, sometimes intransitive, stative) To have a strong affection for (someone or something).
loving.example: I love my spouse.   I love you!

loving.definition: The action of the verb to love.
Expressing a large amount of love to other people; affectionate.

grateful.example: I'm grateful that you helped me out.

blessed.definition: To make something holy by religious rite, sanctify.
Having divine aid, or protection, or other blessing.

comfy.example: The robe and slippers were so warm and comfy she just fell asleep in her chair.

cozy.definition: A padded or knit covering put on an item to keep it warm, especially a teapot or egg.
Affording comfort and warmth; snug; social

ecstatic.definition: (in the plural) Transports of delight; words or actions performed in a state of ecstasy.

elated.definition: Extremely happy and excited; delighted; pleased, euphoric.
elated.example: She was elated with her new car.

excited.example: The fireworks which opened the festivities excited anyone present.
He was very excited about his promotion.

thrilled.definition: To suddenly excite someone, or to give someone great pleasure; to (figuratively) electrify; to experience such a sensation.
To drill and thread in one operation, using a tool bit that cuts the hole and the threads in one series of computer-controlled movements.

thrilled.example: Ben was thrilled to lead the game.

blissful.definition: Extremely happy; full of joy; experiencing, indicating, causing, or characterized by bliss.

fulfilled.definition: To satisfy, carry out, bring to completion (an obligation, a requirement, etc.).
fulfilled.example: You made a promise, son, and now you must fulfill it.

fulfilled.definition: Emotionally satisfied; feeling a sense of fulfilment.

touched.definition: Emotionally moved (by), made to feel emotion (by).
touched.example: I was touched that he should remember my birthday.

balanced.definition: To bring (items) to an equipoise, as the scales of a balance by adjusting the weights.
Containing elements in appropriate proportion; proportionately weighted on all dimensions and therefore unlikely to tip over.
balanced.example: He believed he rarely got sick because of his balanced diet.

carefree.definition: Without cares or worries; free of concern or worries; without difficulty.
carefree.example: He left his cell phone behind and enjoyed a carefree summer day at the beach.

serene.example: She looked at her students with joviality and a serene mentality.
